awd_titl_txt: ADVANCE Catalyst: Diagnosing Intersectional Challenges for Equity in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
The Diagnosing Intersectional Challenges for Equity in STEM (DICES) project will support a two-year self-study at the University of Missouri - Kansas City (UMKC). The self-study aims to identify systemic barriers that affect the recruitment, retention, and success of women faculty in STEM disciplines. UMKC has recently reorganized, creating three new academic units, all of which include STEM disciplines: the School of Science and Engineering, the School of Humanities and Social Science, and the School of Education, Social Work, and Psychological Science. The size and scope of this reorganization bring about a unique opportunity for evidence-based change. The DICES project provides UMKC with the requisite data-informed insight to implement amended policies by identifying policies and procedures contributing to existing inequities. DICES will also provide an opportunity to approach the work of creating new and more equitable academic policies and procedures through an intersectional lens. 
 
UMKC’s broad goals for the DICES project are to (1) Conduct a self-study to identify systemic barriers that affect the recruitment, retention, and success of women faculty in STEM disciplines at UMKC. (2) Use an intersectionality framework for the self-study. (3) Engage best practices on the frontiers of institutional transformation related to STEM gender equity and intersectionality through research, site visits, and consultations. (4) Apply what is learned from the self-study and an innovative pilot study to improve or replace current policies or procedures contributing to inequities and draft a five-year strategic plan for their implementation and assessment. As part of the self-study, UMKC will build a comprehensive dataset to clarify the reasons for existing inequities and increase knowledge about them. The dataset will include: (1) the distribution of STEM faculty by gender, title, and department, (2) the career pathways and recognition for STEM faculty and how those pathways differ by gender and other intersectional identities, (3) the distribution of resource allocation to STEM faculty by gender, title, and department, including salary, start-up packages, research space, graduate assistants, advising, workload assignments and distribution, and (4) the changes to policy, procedure, and other strategies UMKC can implement to promote gender equity.

The NSF ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of diverse faculty in academic institutions. Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in policies, processes, practices, and the organizational culture and climate. ADVANCE "Catalyst" awards provide support for institutional equity assessments and the development of five-year faculty equity strategic plans at an academic, non-profit institution of higher education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE CURATORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI

por.por_cntn:
The Diagnosing Institutional Structures in STEM (DICES) project at the University of Missouri-Kansas City (UMKC) was a research-driven initiative supported by the National Science Foundation ADVANCE Catalyst program. Over two years, the project conducted a comprehensive institutional self-study to examine the structural and procedural factors that influence faculty recruitment, retention, and career progression in STEM disciplines. By applying a data-intensive, analytical approach, the project generated insights to inform long-term improvements in faculty support and advancement. 

Major Activities 

The DICES project employed a multi-method research design, integrating quantitative and qualitative approaches to assess faculty experiences and institutional processes. Key activities included: 

  • The project analyzed human resources and institutional research datasets, encompassing over 500 faculty records spanning several decades. This longitudinal analysis provided a comprehensive understanding of faculty career trajectories, and retention trends. 
  • A secure “walled-garden” computing environment was used to develop and train a machine learning model for textual analysis of personnel letters. While early sentiment analysis proved insufficiently nuanced, iterative refinements demonstrated potential for enhancing clarity and transparency in faculty evaluations. 
  • Faculty and administrators participated in focus groups and structured interviews, providing qualitative insights into institutional practices. These discussions informed the development of strategies for improving clarity and transparency. 
  • Advisory and steering committees, composed of faculty, administrators, and external experts, played a key role in shaping project implementation and refining recommendations. 

Key Findings 

The project identified several structural factors influencing faculty experiences in STEM disciplines at UMKC: 

  • Analysis of faculty promotion timelines indicated variations in the time to full professorship, with influencing factors including service commitments and access to structured mentoring. 
  • Salary data analysis highlighted differences in compensation patterns. Limited data availability on research startup packages and resource distribution underscored the need for improved data tracking mechanisms. 
  • Variability in hiring, evaluation, and advancement procedures highlighted opportunities to strengthen transparency and consistency across departments. 

Major Products 

The project produced several key deliverables that contribute to institutional capacity-building: 

  • A dedicated computing environment was established to support building and training advanced data analysis and machine learning applications. 
  • A prototype language model was developed to analyze faculty evaluation letters, offering a potential framework for enhancing clarity and consistency in written assessments. 
  • A multi-year advancement and retention plan was developed, outlining recommendations for strengthening faculty recruitment, retention, and career progression. 
  • Faculty and administrators participated in training sessions focused on mentoring, workload management, and best practices in faculty evaluation. 

Impact 

The DICES project contributed to an improved understanding of faculty career trajectories and institutional structures at UMKC. Key outcomes include: 

  • The project highlighted areas where data collection and tracking can be improved to support more consistent faculty career analyses. 
  • While still in the early stages, machine learning applications demonstrated potential for enhancing transparency in faculty evaluation processes. 
  • The project’s findings have provided a foundation for discussions on faculty development and retention strategies. 
  • The methodologies piloted in DICES offer a model that can be refined and adapted for continued study of faculty career pathways. 

Challenges and Lessons Learned 

The project encountered several challenges, which informed adaptive strategies: 

  • Gaps in historical data, particularly related to faculty resources and support structures, highlighted the need for enhanced institutional data collection practices. 
  • Over the course of about two decades some faculty have experienced a predictable promotion and tenure path, whereas other faculty, especially those outside of STEM, have not experienced the same level of career timeline predictability. One important challenge moving forward is to reduce that variability with more defined support for research, teaching, and service production milestones. 
  • Early applications of sentiment analysis proved insufficiently nuanced, requiring iterative improvements to machine learning approaches. 
  • Ensuring sustained engagement from faculty and administrators required continuous communication and alignment with institutional priorities. 
Future Directions 

Building on the project’s accomplishments, UMKC is pursuing several initiatives to sustain and expand its impact: 
  • UMKC plans to submit a proposal for additional NSF support to further develop and institutionalize best practices in faculty advancement and retention in STEM. 
  • Ongoing refinements to machine learning tools will enhance their application in faculty evaluation and institutional data analysis. 
  • The strategic recommendations developed through DICES will inform broader efforts to optimize faculty development and career progression strategies. 
  • Partnerships with peer institutions and national organizations will facilitate knowledge exchange and further dissemination of best practices. 

Conclusion 

The DICES project has provided UMKC with valuable data-driven insights into faculty career trajectories and institutional structures in STEM disciplines. By leveraging advanced analytical tools and stakeholder-driven strategies, the initiative has laid the foundation for ongoing improvements in faculty advancement and retention. The project’s findings and methodologies offer a scalable model for institutions seeking to strengthen faculty support and enhance academic career pathways in STEM fields.

 


Last Modified: 02/06/2025
Modified by: Alexis N Petri
por.por_txt_cntn:
The Diagnosing Institutional Structures in STEM (DICES) project at the University of Missouri-Kansas City (UMKC) was a research-driven initiative supported by the National Science Foundation ADVANCE Catalyst program. Over two years, the project conducted a comprehensive institutional self-study to examine the structural and procedural factors that influence faculty recruitment, retention, and career progression in STEM disciplines. By applying a data-intensive, analytical approach, the project generated insights to inform long-term improvements in faculty support and advancement.




Major Activities




The DICES project employed a multi-method research design, integrating quantitative and qualitative approaches to assess faculty experiences and institutional processes. Key activities included:



The project analyzed human resources and institutional research datasets, encompassing over 500 faculty records spanning several decades. This longitudinal analysis provided a comprehensive understanding of faculty career trajectories, and retention trends.




A secure walled-garden computing environment was used to develop and train a machine learning model for textual analysis of personnel letters. While early sentiment analysis proved insufficiently nuanced, iterative refinements demonstrated potential for enhancing clarity and transparency in faculty evaluations.




Faculty and administrators participated in focus groups and structured interviews, providing qualitative insights into institutional practices. These discussions informed the development of strategies for improving clarity and transparency.




 Advisory and steering committees, composed of faculty, administrators, and external experts, played a key role in shaping project implementation and refining recommendations.





Key Findings




The project identified several structural factors influencing faculty experiences in STEM disciplines at UMKC:



Analysis of faculty promotion timelines indicated variations in the time to full professorship, with influencing factors including service commitments and access to structured mentoring.




Salary data analysis highlighted differences in compensation patterns. Limited data availability on research startup packages and resource distribution underscored the need for improved data tracking mechanisms.




Variability in hiring, evaluation, and advancement procedures highlighted opportunities to strengthen transparency and consistency across departments.





Major Products




The project produced several key deliverables that contribute to institutional capacity-building:



A dedicated computing environment was established to support building and training advanced data analysis and machine learning applications.




A prototype language model was developed to analyze faculty evaluation letters, offering a potential framework for enhancing clarity and consistency in written assessments.




A multi-year advancement and retention plan was developed, outlining recommendations for strengthening faculty recruitment, retention, and career progression.




Faculty and administrators participated in training sessions focused on mentoring, workload management, and best practices in faculty evaluation.





Impact




The DICES project contributed to an improved understanding of faculty career trajectories and institutional structures at UMKC. Key outcomes include:



The project highlighted areas where data collection and tracking can be improved to support more consistent faculty career analyses.
 While still in the early stages, machine learning applications demonstrated potential for enhancing transparency in faculty evaluation processes.


 The projects findings have provided a foundation for discussions on faculty development and retention strategies.


 The methodologies piloted in DICES offer a model that can be refined and adapted for continued study of faculty career pathways.





Challenges and Lessons Learned




The project encountered several challenges, which informed adaptive strategies:



Gaps in historical data, particularly related to faculty resources and support structures, highlighted the need for enhanced institutional data collection practices.
 Over the course of about two decades some faculty have experienced a predictable promotion and tenure path, whereas other faculty, especially those outside of STEM, have not experienced the same level of career timeline predictability. One important challenge moving forward is to reduce that variability with more defined support for research, teaching, and service production milestones.


 Early applications of sentiment analysis proved insufficiently nuanced, requiring iterative improvements to machine learning approaches.


 Ensuring sustained engagement from faculty and administrators required continuous communication and alignment with institutional priorities.

Future Directions


Building on the projects accomplishments, UMKC is pursuing several initiatives to sustain and expand its impact:

 UMKC plans to submit a proposal for additional NSF support to further develop and institutionalize best practices in faculty advancement and retention in STEM.


 Ongoing refinements to machine learning tools will enhance their application in faculty evaluation and institutional data analysis.


 The strategic recommendations developed through DICES will inform broader efforts to optimize faculty development and career progression strategies.


 Partnerships with peer institutions and national organizations will facilitate knowledge exchange and further dissemination of best practices.





Conclusion




The DICES project has provided UMKC with valuable data-driven insights into faculty career trajectories and institutional structures in STEM disciplines. By leveraging advanced analytical tools and stakeholder-driven strategies, the initiative has laid the foundation for ongoing improvements in faculty advancement and retention. The projects findings and methodologies offer a scalable model for institutions seeking to strengthen faculty support and enhance academic career pathways in STEM fields.
